evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the early phase of the historical timeline for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters based on the available evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the early historical timeline, with no contradictory information undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the early historical timeline, including crew interactions and coordination challenges.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the early phase of the historical timeline for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: Communication between tug crew and flight crew is representative of overall crew communication
The early phase of the timeline corresponds to the events described in the evidence
defeaters: Direct evidence of communication breakdown among flight crew during early phase
Clear indication that communication was effective and no breakdown occurred

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows communication between flight crew and headset operator and coordination between tug instructor and trainee during pushback, but no direct indication of a communication/coordination breakdown among the flight crew during the early phase of the timeline (H1-H5). The incident with the aircraft moving beyond the TRP suggests a possible coordination issue but does not explicitly confirm a communication breakdown among the crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit statements about communication breakdown among crew in early timeline

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
